text:
Department: Anesthesia Preoperative Program
Department Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24
Procedure Location: Your procedure time and location have not been confirmed. If you have not heard from us the night before surgery by 6:30 PM, please call 650-723-5163.

The Endoscopy Lab will confirm your procedure start time. They will call before 3 PM the day before your surgery (or the Friday before a Monday surgery) to confirm your arrival and surgery start times. If you do not hear from them by 3 PM, please call (650) 736-5555.

Procedure Location:
Endoscopy: Located at 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, Ground floor.

Directions:
- From the entrance of the hospital, take the elevator to the ground floor.
- Make a right when exiting the elevator.
- Follow the RED way finder signs to C06 Endoscopy.

Eating and Drinking Instructions:

1. PLEASE FOLLOW YOUR SURGEON'S/PROCEDURALIST'S EATING AND DRINKING INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE SURGERY/PROCEDURE.

2. If you have NOT received eating and drinking instructions from your surgeon, please follow these instructions:
- Do not eat any food or solids, candy or gum, starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
- Do not drink any dairy/milk/soy products (protein shakes) starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
- You may drink the following clear liquids: tea, black coffee (no cream), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Do not drink anything with pulp.
- You may continue to drink clear liquids (see above for examples) up until 4 hours before your procedure/surgery time.
- On the day of the procedure/surgery, take your morning medications as instructed with sips of water.

Transportation:
Remember, you must arrange for an adult to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or ride share driver is not acceptable unless you have a responsible adult to accompany you home. Due to COVID-19, our Valet parking is suspended.

Personal Items:
Remember to dress comfortably. Leave valuables at home. Please do not wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercing, or contact lenses. Please bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you may be requested to provide a co-payment and/or deductible.

Preoperative Medication Management (see medication list below):
1 week before your procedure, do not take herbal supplements and fish oils.

For Endoscopy procedures, if you are taking Aspirin and/or NSAIDS (Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs) such as Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and/or Naprosyn, please continue taking them. If you are on any anti-coagulation and/or anti-platelet medication, please contact Endoscopy for further instructions at (650) 736-5555.

If you are on anti-coagulation and/or anti-platelet medication such as: coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta) or other similar blood thinners, please contact your surgeon for further instructions.

Other information:
If your procedure is scheduled at 300P, 500P, or Lane Surgery Center, please bring your CPAP mask (not machine) on the day of surgery. If you are being admitted or staying overnight, bring your mask and machine (with settings).

If you experience any new developments in your health such as cold/flu, possible symptoms or exposure to COVID-19, worsening of an existing health condition, recent hospitalizations, or any new concerning symptoms following your anesthesia preoperative visit, please call us at (650) 498-5332.

text:
Department: Anesthesia Preoperative Program
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions

Procedure Date: 01/14/24
Procedure Location: YOUR PROCEDURE TIME AND LOCATION HAVE NOT BEEN CONFIRMED. IF YOU HAVE NOT HEARD FROM US THE NIGHT BEFORE SURGERY BY 6:30 PM, PLEASE CALL 650-723-5163

New Stanford Hospital (500P) Pre-Procedure Unit will confirm your procedure start time. They will call you the day before surgery (or the Friday before a Monday surgery) to confirm your arrival time and surgery start time. Please be aware your surgery time is subject to change. If you do not hear from them by 5:00 PM the evening prior to surgery, please call (650) 497-3157.

Procedure Location:
New Stanford Hospital (500p).
DIRECTION: Located at 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.

Take Elevator M bank (#5, #6, #7, or #8) located on the right side of the Atrium entrance.

Eating and Drinking Instructions:

1. PLEASE FOLLOW YOUR SURGEON'S/PROCEDURALIST'S EATING AND DRINKING INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE SURGERY/PROCEDURE.

2. If you have NOT received eating and drinking instructions from your surgeon, please follow these instructions:
   - Do not eat any food or solids, candy or gum, starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
   - Do not drink any dairy/milk/soy products (protein shakes) starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
   - You may drink clear liquids such as tea, black coffee (no cream), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Do not drink anything with pulp.
   - You may continue to drink clear liquids (see above for examples) up until 4 hours before your procedure/surgery time.
   - On the day of the procedure/surgery, take your morning medications as instructed with sips of water.

Transportation:
Remember you must arrange for an adult to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or ride share driver is not acceptable unless you have a responsible adult to accompany you home. Due to COVID-19, our Valet parking is suspended.

Personal Items:
Remember to dress comfortably. Leave valuables at home. Please do not wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercing, or contact lenses. Please bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you may be requested to provide a co-payment and/or deductible.

Preoperative Medication Management (see medication list below):
- 1 week before your procedure, do not take herbal supplements and fish oils.
- 1 week before your procedure, do not take NSAIDs (Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs) such as Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and/or Naprosyn. You may take Acetaminophen such as Tylenol.
- If you are on anti-coagulation and/or anti-platelet medication such as coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta), or other similar blood thinners, please contact your surgeon for further instructions.

Other information:
Regional Block After Visit Summary
The plan for your anesthesia may depend on the type of surgery you may be having. You may require regional anesthesia for your upcoming surgery.

What is Regional Anesthesia, also called a "nerve block"?
A nerve block is an injection of local anesthetic, or numbing medication, administered in a muscle that is near or around a specific nerve or group of nerves. This will help decrease or completely "block" sensation to the area to better control your pain during and after surgery. This procedure is done by an anesthesiologist who is specially trained for Regional Anesthesia. With a nerve block, you may remain awake, receive IV sedation, or general anesthesia in the operating room.

What are the benefits of having a Regional block?
1. Faster recovery from anesthesia
2. Better pain control than opioid (narcotic) pain medications alone
3. Decreased need for opioid pain medications, and therefore fewer side effects such as sedation, nausea, constipation, and itching
4. About 3-24 hours of pain relief after a single injection of numbing medication
5. Up to 3-4 days of pain relief with a local infusion also called a "nerve block pump."

What type of nerve block will I receive?
Depending on your health, type of surgery, and your preference, your Regional Anesthesiologist will discuss your options on the day of your surgery.

1. Single injection nerve block is a one-time injection of local anesthetic that will numb, or "block" sensation around the nerve. The duration of the block depends on the medication used and the effects can last between 3 to 24 hours.

2. Nerve block pump is a continuous delivery of local anesthetic given through an indwelling catheter. The catheter is the size of a guitar string and it is securely taped to your skin. Should you need additional numbing medication, you can administer a bolus by pressing a button on the pump. The nerve pump can be kept for 3-4 days or until the local anesthesia medicine runs out.

What are the risks of regional anesthesia?
Like any other medical procedure, there are risks associated with regional anesthesia. Complications or side effects can occur and can include infection, bleeding, damage to surrounding tissues including blood vessels or muscle tissue, reaction to the medication, failure of the numbing medicine to have an effect, or stopping the procedure for any reason. To minimize many of these risks, the regional anesthesiologist uses an ultrasound machine to guide the placement of the block. It is done using a sterile technique to minimize the risk of infection. The specific risks may vary with the procedure and the medical condition of the patient.
On the morning of your surgery, you will meet members from the Regional Anesthesia team to answer any additional questions and discuss a plan that works best for you.

What time am I expected to come in for surgery?
You will be requested to come 2-2 ½ hours before surgery time.

What time will the Preop Area call me to give me the time to come in for surgery?
The Preop Area will call you by 6 pm the night before surgery or Friday evening before Monday's surgery.

Will I need additional pain medication with a nerve block?
Yes. Your surgeon may prescribe additional pain medications by mouth. Upon discharge, you will be provided with instructions.

If you experience any new developments in your health such as cold/flu, possible symptoms or exposure to COVID-19, worsening of an existing health condition, recent hospitalizations, or any new concerning symptoms following your anesthesia preoperative visit, please call us (650) 498-5332.

Procedure Location: YOUR PROCEDURE TIME AND LOCATION HAVE NOT BEEN CONFIRMED. IF YOU HAVE NOT HEARD FROM US THE NIGHT BEFORE SURGERY BY 6:30 PM, PLEASE CALL 650-723-5163

New Stanford Hospital (500P) Pre-Procedure Unit will confirm your procedure start time. They will call you the day before surgery (or the Friday before a Monday surgery) to confirm your arrival time and surgery start time. Please be aware your surgery time is subject to change. If you do not hear from them by 5:00 PM the evening prior to surgery, please call (650) 497-3157.

Procedure Location:
New Stanford Hospital (500p). DIRECTION: Located at 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
Take Elevator M bank (#5, #6, #7, or #8) located on the right side of the Atrium entrance.

Eating and Drinking Instructions:

1. PLEASE FOLLOW YOUR SURGEON'S/PROCEDURALIST'S EATING AND DRINKING INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE SURGERY/PROCEDURE.

2. If you have NOT received eating and drinking instructions from your surgeon, please follow these instructions:
- Do not eat any food or solids, candy or gum, starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
- Do not drink any dairy/milk/soy products (protein shakes) starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
- You may drink the following clear liquids: tea, black coffee (no cream), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Do not drink anything with pulp.
- You may continue to drink clear liquids (see above for examples) up until 4 hours before your procedure/surgery time.
- On the day of the procedure/surgery, take your morning medications as instructed with sips of water.

Transportation:
Remember you must arrange for an adult to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or ride share driver is not acceptable unless you have a responsible adult to accompany you home. Due to COVID-19, our Valet parking is suspended.

Personal Items:
Remember to dress comfortably. Leave valuables at home. Please do not wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercing, or contact lenses. Please bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you may be requested to provide a co-payment and/or deductible.

Preoperative Medication Management (see medication list below):
- 1 week before your procedure, do not take herbal supplements and fish oils.
- 1 week before your procedure, do not take NSAIDs (Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs) such as Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and/or Naprosyn. You may take Acetaminophen such as Tylenol.
- If you are on anti-coagulation and/or anti-platelet medication such as: coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta) or other similar blood thinners, please contact your surgeon for further instructions.

Other information:
If you experience any new developments in your health such as cold/flu, possible symptoms or exposure to COVID-19, worsening of an existing health condition, recent hospitalizations, or any new concerning symptoms following your anesthesia preoperative visit, please call us (650) 498-5332.

Department: Anesthesia Preoperative Program
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions

Procedure Date: 01/14/24
Procedure Location: YOUR PROCEDURE TIME AND LOCATION HAVE NOT BEEN CONFIRMED. IF YOU HAVE NOT HEARD FROM US THE NIGHT BEFORE SURGERY BY 6:30 PM, PLEASE CALL 650-723-5163

New Stanford Hospital (500P) Pre-Procedure Unit will confirm your procedure start time. They will call you the day before surgery (or the Friday before a Monday surgery) to confirm your arrival time and surgery start time. Please be aware your surgery time is subject to change. If you do not hear from them by 5:00 PM the evening prior to surgery, please call (650) 497-3157.

Procedure Location:
New Stanford Hospital (500p).
DIRECTION: Located at 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.

Take Elevator M bank (#5, #6, #7, or #8) located on the right side of the Atrium entrance.

Eating and Drinking Instructions:

1. PLEASE FOLLOW YOUR SURGEON'S/PROCEDURALIST'S EATING AND DRINKING INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE SURGERY/PROCEDURE.

2. If you have NOT received eating and drinking instructions from your surgeon, please follow these instructions:
- Do not eat any food or solids, candy or gum, starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
- Do not drink any dairy/milk/soy products (protein shakes) starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
- You may drink clear liquids such as tea, black coffee (no cream), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Do not drink anything with pulp.
- You may continue to drink clear liquids (see above for examples) up until 4 hours before your procedure/surgery time.
- On the day of the procedure/surgery, take your morning medications as instructed with sips of water.

Transportation:
Remember you must arrange for an adult to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or ride share driver is not acceptable unless you have a responsible adult to accompany you home. Due to COVID-19, our Valet parking is suspended.

Personal Items:
Remember to dress comfortably. Leave valuables at home. Please do not wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercing, or contact lenses. Please bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you may be requested to provide a co-payment and/or deductible.

Preoperative Medication Management (see medication list below):
1 week before your procedure, do not take herbal supplements and fish oils.
1 week before your procedure, do not take NSAIDs (Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs) such as Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and/or Naprosyn. You may take Acetaminophen such as Tylenol.
If you are on anti-coagulation and/or anti-platelet medication such as: coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta) or other similar blood thinners, please contact your surgeon for further instructions.

Other information:
Regional Block After Visit Summary
The plan for your anesthesia may depend on the type of surgery you may be having. You may require regional anesthesia for your upcoming surgery.

What is Regional Anesthesia, also called a "nerve block"?
A nerve block is an injection of local anesthetic, or numbing medication, administered in a muscle that is near or around a specific nerve or group of nerves. This will help decrease or completely "block" sensation to the area to better control your pain during and after surgery. This procedure is done by an anesthesiologist who is specially trained for Regional Anesthesia. With a nerve block, you may remain awake, receive IV sedation, or general anesthesia in the operating room.

What are the benefits of having a Regional block?
1. Faster recovery from anesthesia
2. Better pain control than opioid (narcotic) pain medications alone
3. Decreased need for opioid pain medications, and therefore fewer side effects such as sedation, nausea, constipation, and itching
4. About 3-24 hours of pain relief after a single injection of numbing medication
5. Up to 3-4 days of pain relief with a local infusion also called a "nerve block pump."

What type of nerve block will I receive?
Depending on your health, type of surgery, and your preference, your Regional Anesthesiologist will discuss your options on the day of your surgery.

1. Single injection nerve block is a one-time injection of local anesthetic that will numb, or "block" sensation around the nerve. The duration of the block depends on the medication used and the effects can last between 3 to 24 hours.

2. Nerve block pump is a continuous delivery of local anesthetic given through an indwelling catheter. The catheter is the size of a guitar string and it is securely taped to your skin. Should you need additional numbing medication, you can administer a bolus by pressing a button on the pump. The nerve pump can be kept for 3-4 days or until the local anesthesia medicine runs out.

What are the risks of regional anesthesia?
Like any other medical procedure, there are risks associated with regional anesthesia. Complications or side effects can occur and can include infection, bleeding, damage to surrounding tissues including blood vessels or muscle tissue, reaction to the medication, failure of the numbing medicine to have an effect, or stopping the procedure for any reason. To minimize many of these risks, the regional anesthesiologist uses an ultrasound machine to guide the placement of the block. It is done using a sterile technique to minimize the risk of infection. The specific risks may vary with the procedure and the medical condition of the patient.
On the morning of your surgery, you will meet members from the Regional Anesthesia team to answer any additional questions and discuss a plan that works best for you.

What time am I expected to come in for surgery?
You will be requested to come 2-2 ½ hours before surgery time.

What time will the Preop Area call me to give me the time to come in for surgery?
The Preop Area will call you by 6 pm the night before surgery or Friday evening before Monday's surgery.

Will I need additional pain medication with a nerve block?
Yes. Your surgeon may prescribe additional pain medications by mouth. Upon discharge, you will be provided with instructions.

If you experience any new developments in your health such as cold/flu, possible symptoms or exposure to COVID-19, worsening of an existing health condition, recent hospitalizations, or any new concerning symptoms following your anesthesia preoperative visit, please call us (650) 498-5332.

- If you are on anti-coagulation and/or anti-platelet medication such as: coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta) or other similar blood thinners, please contact your surgeon for further instructions.

text:
Department: Anesthesia Preoperative Program
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions

Procedure Date: 01/14/24
Procedure Location: YOUR PROCEDURE TIME AND LOCATION HAVE NOT BEEN CONFIRMED. IF YOU HAVE NOT HEARD FROM US THE NIGHT BEFORE SURGERY BY 6:30 PM, PLEASE CALL 650-723-5163

New Stanford Hospital (500P) Pre-Procedure Unit will confirm your procedure start time. They will call you the day before surgery (or the Friday before a Monday surgery) to confirm your arrival time and surgery start time. Please be aware your surgery time is subject to change. If you do not hear from them by 5:00 PM the evening prior to surgery, please call (650) 497-3157.

Procedure Location:
New Stanford Hospital (500p).
DIRECTION: Located at 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.

Take Elevator M bank (#5, #6, #7, or #8) located on the right side of the Atrium entrance.

Eating and Drinking Instructions:

1. PLEASE FOLLOW YOUR SURGEON'S/PROCEDURALIST'S EATING AND DRINKING INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE SURGERY/PROCEDURE.

2. If you have NOT received eating and drinking instructions from your surgeon, please follow these instructions:
   - Do not eat any food or solids, candy or gum, starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
   - Do not drink any dairy/milk/soy products (protein shakes) starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
   - You may drink clear liquids such as tea, black coffee (no cream), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Do not drink anything with pulp.
   - You may continue to drink clear liquids (see above for examples) up until 4 hours before your procedure/surgery time.
   - On the day of the procedure/surgery, take your morning medications as instructed with sips of water.

Transportation:
Remember you must arrange for an adult to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or ride share driver is not acceptable unless you have a responsible adult to accompany you home. Due to COVID-19, our Valet parking is suspended.

Personal Items:
Remember to dress comfortably. Leave valuables at home. Please do not wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercing, or contact lenses. Please bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you may be requested to provide a co-payment and/or deductible.

Preoperative Medication Management (see medication list below):
1 week before your procedure, do not take herbal supplements and fish oils.
1 week before your procedure, do not take NSAIDs (Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs) such as Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and/or Naprosyn. You may take Acetaminophen such as Tylenol.
If you are on anti-coagulation and/or anti-platelet medication such as: coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta) or other similar blood thinners, please contact your surgeon for further instructions.

Other information:
Regional Block After Visit Summary
The plan for your anesthesia may depend on the type of surgery you may be having. You may require regional anesthesia for your upcoming surgery.

What is Regional Anesthesia, also called a "nerve block"?
A nerve block is an injection of local anesthetic, or numbing medication, administered in a muscle that is near or around a specific nerve or group of nerves. This will help decrease or completely "block" sensation to the area to better control your pain during and after surgery. This procedure is done by an anesthesiologist who is specially trained for Regional Anesthesia. With a nerve block, you may remain awake, receive IV sedation, or general anesthesia in the operating room.

What are the benefits of having a Regional block?
1. Faster recovery from anesthesia
2. Better pain control than opioid (narcotic) pain medications alone
3. Decreased need for opioid pain medications, and therefore fewer side effects such as sedation, nausea, constipation, and itching
4. About 3-24 hours of pain relief after a single injection of numbing medication
5. Up to 3-4 days of pain relief with a local infusion also called a "nerve block pump."

What type of nerve block will I receive?
Depending on your health, type of surgery, and your preference, your Regional Anesthesiologist will discuss your options on the day of your surgery.
1. Single injection nerve block is a one-time injection of local anesthetic that will numb, or "block" sensation around the nerve. The duration of the block depends on the medication used and the effects can last between 3 to 24 hours.
2. Nerve block pump is a continuous delivery of local anesthetic given through an indwelling catheter. The catheter is the size of a guitar string and it is securely taped to your skin. Should you need additional numbing medication, you can administer a bolus by pressing a button on the pump. The nerve pump can be kept for 3-4 days or until the local anesthesia medicine runs out.

What are the risks of regional anesthesia?
Like any other medical procedure, there are risks associated with regional anesthesia. Complications or side effects can occur and can include infection, bleeding, damage to surrounding tissues including blood vessels or muscle tissue, reaction to the medication, failure of the numbing medicine to have an effect, or stopping the procedure for any reason. To minimize many of these risks, the regional anesthesiologist uses an ultrasound machine to guide the placement of the block. It is done using a sterile technique to minimize the risk of infection. The specific risks may vary with the procedure and the medical condition of the patient.
On the morning of your surgery, you will meet members from the Regional Anesthesia team to answer any additional questions and discuss a plan that works best for you.

What time am I expected to come in for surgery?
You will be requested to come 2-2 ½ hours before surgery time.

What time will the Preop Area call me to give me the time to come in for surgery?
The Preop Area will call you by 6 pm the night before surgery or Friday evening before Monday's surgery.

Will I need additional pain medication with a nerve block?
Yes. Your surgeon may prescribe additional pain medications by mouth. Upon discharge, you will be provided with instructions.

If you experience any new developments in your health such as cold/flu, possible symptoms or exposure to COVID-19, worsening of an existing health condition, recent hospitalizations, or any new concerning symptoms following your anesthesia preoperative visit, please call us (650) 498-5332.

What are the benefits of having a Regional block?
1. Faster recovery from anesthesia
2. Better pain control than opioid (narcotic) pain medications alone
3. Decreased need for opioid pain medications, and therefore fewer side effects such as sedation, nausea, constipation, and itching
4. About 3-24 hours of pain relief after a single injection of numbing medication
5. Up to 3-4 days of pain relief with a local infusion also called a "nerve block pump."

What type of nerve block will I receive?
Depending on your health, type of surgery, and your preference, your Regional Anesthesiologist will discuss your options on the day of your surgery.
1. Single injection nerve block is a one-time injection of local anesthetic that will numb, or "block" sensation around the nerve. The duration of the block depends on the medication used and the effects can last between 3 to 24 hours.
2. Nerve block pump is a continuous delivery of local anesthetic given through an indwelling catheter. The catheter is the size of a guitar string and it is securely taped to your skin. Should you need additional numbing medication, you can administer a bolus by pressing a button on the pump. The nerve pump can be kept for 3-4 days or until the local anesthesia medicine runs out.

What are the risks of regional anesthesia?
Like any other medical procedure, there are risks associated with regional anesthesia. Complications or side effects can occur and can include infection, bleeding, damage to surrounding tissues including blood vessels or muscle tissue, reaction to the medication, failure of the numbing medicine to have an effect, or stopping the procedure for any reason. To minimize many of these risks, the regional anesthesiologist uses an ultrasound machine to guide the placement of the block. It is done using a sterile technique to minimize the risk of infection. The specific risks may vary with the procedure and the medical condition of the patient.
On the morning of your surgery, you will meet members from the Regional Anesthesia team to answer any additional questions and discuss a plan that works best for you.

What time am I expected to come in for surgery?
You will be requested to come 2-2 ½ hours before surgery time.

What time will the Preop Area call me to give me the time to come in for surgery?
The Preop Area will call you by 6 pm the night before surgery or Friday evening before Monday's surgery.

Will I need additional pain medication with a nerve block?
Yes. Your surgeon may prescribe additional pain medications by mouth. Upon discharge, you will be provided with instructions.

If you experience any new developments in your health such as cold/flu, possible symptoms or exposure to COVID-19, worsening of an existing health condition, recent hospitalizations, or any new concerning symptoms following your anesthesia preoperative visit, please call us (650) 498-5332.

text:
Department: Anesthesia Preoperative Program
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24
Procedure Location: Your procedure time and location have not been confirmed. If you have not heard from us the night before surgery by 6:30 PM, please call 650-723-5163.

The Lane (Ambulatory) Surgery Center will confirm your procedure start time. They will call you the day before surgery (or the Friday before a Monday surgery) to confirm your arrival and surgery start times. If you do not hear from them by 6 PM, please call 650-723-7125.

Procedure Location:
300P Operating Room. Located at 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, Pavilion E25, Surgical Admission Unit/Anesthesia Pre-Evaluation Clinic.

Directions:
- At the main entrance of the hospital, make a left inside.
- Take the "E" elevator to the 2nd floor.
- Make a left as you exit the elevator and go through the double doors.
- Pavilion E25 - Surgical Admission Unit/Anesthesia Pre-Evaluation Clinic is located as you enter the double doors.

Eating and Drinking Instructions:
1. Please follow your surgeon's/proceduralist's eating and drinking instructions before surgery/procedure.
2. If you have not received eating and drinking instructions from your surgeon, please follow these instructions:
- Do not eat any food or solids, candy or gum, starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
- Do not drink any dairy/milk/soy products (protein shakes) starting at midnight the evening before your procedure/surgery.
- You may drink the following clear liquids: tea, black coffee (no cream), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Do not drink anything with pulp.
- You may continue to drink clear liquids (see above for examples) up until 4 hours before your procedure/surgery time.
- On the day of the procedure/surgery, take your morning medications as instructed with sips of water.

Transportation:
Remember, you must arrange for an adult to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or ride share driver is not acceptable unless you have a responsible adult to accompany you home. Due to COVID-19, our Valet parking is suspended.

Personal Items:
Remember to dress comfortably. Leave valuables at home. Please do not wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercing, or contact lenses. Please bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you may be requested to provide a co-payment and/or deductible.

Preoperative Medication Management (see medication list below):
- 1 week before your procedure, do not take herbal supplements and fish oils.
- 1 week before your procedure, do not take NSAIDs (Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs) such as Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and/or Naprosyn. You may take Acetaminophen such as Tylenol.
- If you are on anti-coagulation and/or anti-platelet medication such as: coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta) or other similar blood thinners, please contact your surgeon for further instructions.

Other information:
- If your procedure is scheduled at 300P, 500P, or Lane Surgery Center, please bring your CPAP mask (not machine) on the day of surgery. If you are being admitted or staying overnight, bring your mask and machine (with settings).
- If you experience any new developments in your health such as cold/flu, possible symptoms or exposure to COVID-19, worsening of an existing health condition, recent hospitalizations, or any new concerning symptoms following your anesthesia preoperative visit, please call us at 650-498-5332.

- 1 week before your procedure, do not take NSAIDs (Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs) such as Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and/or Naprosyn. You may take Acetaminophen such as Tylenol.
- If you are on anti-coagulation and/or anti-platelet medication such as: coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta) or other similar blood thinners, please contact your surgeon for further instructions.

Other information:
- If your procedure is scheduled at 300P, 500P, or Lane Surgery Center, please bring your CPAP mask (not machine) on the day of surgery. If you are being admitted or staying overnight, bring your mask and machine (with settings).
- If you experience any new developments in your health such as cold/flu, possible symptoms or exposure to COVID-19, worsening of an existing health condition, recent hospitalizations, or any new concerning symptoms following your anesthesia preoperative visit, please call us at (650) 498-5332.

text:
Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24

Hello! Here's what you need to know before your surgery:

Procedure Time and Place:
- If we haven't told you when and where your surgery is by the night before, call us at 650-723-5163 by 6:30 PM.

The Endoscopy Lab will let you know your surgery time. They'll call by 3 PM the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday). If you don't hear from them, call (650) 736-5555.

Where to Go:
Endoscopy is at 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, Ground floor.

How to Get There:
- Go into the hospital and take the elevator to the ground floor.
- Turn right when you leave the elevator.
- Follow the RED signs to C06 Endoscopy.

Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.

2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's the plan:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't have milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight either.
- You can have clear liquids like tea (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
- You can drink these clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

Getting Home:
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. No taxis or ride shares unless another adult is with you.

What to Bring and Wear:
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave your valuable things at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal things, or contact lenses.
- Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Medicines Before Surgery:
- Stop taking herbal stuff and fish oils 1 week before surgery.

For Endoscopy:
- Keep taking Aspirin and pain relievers like Advil or Aleve.
- If you're on blood thinners like Warfarin, Plavix, or others, call your doctor.

Other Important Stuff:
- If your surgery is at 300P, 500P, or Lane Surgery Center, bring your CPAP mask (not the machine) on the day of surgery. If you're staying overnight, bring the mask and machine.
- If you get sick, think you have COVID-19, or have other health worries after your last doctor visit, call us at (650) 498-5332.

- Don't have milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight either.
- You can have clear drinks like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
- You can drink these clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of surgery, take any morning medicine with small sips of water.

Getting Home:
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare alone.

- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things like jewelry at home.

text:
Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24

Hello! Here's what you need to know before your surgery:

- If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.
- The Byers Eye Institute Surgery Center will tell you when to come in for your surgery. They'll call you the day before, or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday. If you don't hear from them by 5 PM, call (650) 725-1651 after 6 PM and leave a message.

Where to go:
Byers Eye Institute Surgery Center
2452 Watson Court, Palo Alto, 1st floor

How to get there:
- Walk into the Byers Eye Institute.
- Head to the back of the building.
- Turn right to find the Surgery Center.

What to eat and drink:

1. Your doctor might give you special instructions about eating and drinking. Please follow those.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's the plan:
   - No food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - No milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight, too.
   - You can have clear liquids like tea (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it, like pulp.
   - You can drink these clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of your surgery, take any morning pills with small sips of water.

Getting home:
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. Taxis or ride shares are okay only if an adult is with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

What to bring and wear:
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things like jewelry at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contacts.
- Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Medicines before surgery:
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Don't take pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen for 1 week before. Tylenol is okay.
- If you have eye surgery and take Aspirin or blood thinners, call your eye doctor.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Plavix, Eliquis, or others, talk to your surgeon.

If you get sick or something changes:
- If you feel sick, like with a cold or flu, or you've been near someone with COVID-19, let us know.
- If your health gets worse, you go to the hospital, or anything else worries you after your pre-surgery visit, call us at (650) 498-5332.

We want to make sure you're safe and ready for your surgery!

text:
----------------

Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24

**Procedure Location and Time:**
- If you don't know when or where your surgery is by the night before, call us at 650-723-5163 by 6:30 PM.

**Before Your Surgery:**
- The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will tell you when to come in for your surgery. They'll call you the day before, or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday.
- If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, please call 650-497-3157.

**Where to Go:**
- New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit, at 500 Pasteur Dr.
- Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**
- Follow what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
- If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, don't eat food, candy, or gum after midnight before your surgery. No dairy, milk, or soy drinks either.
- You can have clear drinks like tea without milk, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks without pulp.
- Stop drinking anything 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. Taxis or ride shares are okay only if an adult is with you.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contacts.
- Bring a photo ID and your insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Don't take pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen a week before. Tylenol is okay.
- If you take blood thinners, talk to your surgeon about what to do.

**About Nerve Blocks:**
- A nerve block is a shot that numbs an area for surgery.
- It helps with pain and can mean you need fewer painkillers.
- The numbing can last from a few hours to a few days.
- Your doctor will talk to you about what kind of nerve block is best for you.
- Nerve blocks are safe, but like all treatments, there are some risks. Your doctor will work to keep risks low.

**Day of Surgery:**
- Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time.
- The Preop Area will call you by 6 PM the night before to tell you when to come in.

**Pain Medicine:**
- You might need more pain medicine after surgery. Your doctor will give you instructions.

**If You Get Sick:**
- If you feel sick or think you might have COVID-19, or if your health changes, call us at 650-498-5332.

The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will tell you when to come in for your surgery. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to let you know when to arrive and when your surgery will start. Remember, your surgery time could change. If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, call (650) 497-3157.

**Where to Go:**
New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
**How to Get There:** Go to 500 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital. Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side after you enter.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking before surgery.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't drink milk, soy drinks, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
   - You can have clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of surgery, take your morning medicine with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless an adult is with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
Wear comfy clothes. Leave valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses. Bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicine Before Surgery:**

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn 1 week before surgery. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your doctor about what to do.

**About Nerve Blocks:**
A nerve block is a shot that makes part of your body numb for surgery. It helps with pain during and after surgery. You might stay awake or get medicine to make you sleepy or fully asleep.

**Benefits of a Nerve Block:**

- You might wake up faster after surgery.
- It can control pain better than just pain pills.
- You might not need as many pain pills, so you'll have fewer side effects like sleepiness, upset stomach, constipation, or itchiness.
- The numb feeling can last 3-24 hours, or even 3-4 days with a special pump.

**Types of Nerve Blocks:**

1. A single shot that lasts 3-24 hours.
2. A pump that gives medicine for up to 3-4 days.

**Risks of Nerve Blocks:**
There are some risks, like infection, bleeding, tissue damage, or the medicine not working. The doctor will use special tools to lower these risks.

**Surgery Day Info:**

- Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery.
- We'll call you by 6 PM the night before your surgery to tell you when to come in.

**Will I Need More Pain Medicine?**
Yes, you might get more pain medicine to take by mouth. We'll tell you what to do when you leave the hospital.

**If You Get Sick:**
If you feel sick, like you have a cold or the flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, or if you have new health problems, call us at (650) 498-5332.

Getting Home:
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless another adult is with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

**Anesthesia Pre-Op Program**
**Phone:** 650-555-5555

**Pre-Op Instructions**
**Surgery Date:** 01/14/24

**Where is my surgery?**
Your surgery time and place are not set yet. If we don't call you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

**Where to go for your surgery:**
New Stanford Hospital (500P) Pre-Procedure Unit. They will tell you when to come in. If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, call (650) 497-3157.

**Address:**
New Stanford Hospital (500P), 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital.

**How to get there:**
Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
3. Don't drink milk, soy, or shakes after midnight the night before.
4. You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
5. You can have these clear drinks until 4 hours before your surgery.
6. On the day of your surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare alone.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
Wear comfy clothes. Leave valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal things, or contacts. Bring your ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Plavix, or others, talk to your doctor.

**About Nerve Blocks:**
A nerve block is a shot that numbs an area for surgery. It helps with pain and can last from a few hours to a few days. Your doctor will talk to you about it on the day of surgery.

**Risks of Nerve Blocks:**
There are some risks like infection or not working well. The doctor will use a clean method and a special machine to lower these risks.

**When to Arrive for Surgery:**
Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time.

**When Will They Call Me?**
They will call you by 6 PM the night before your surgery to tell you when to come in.

**Will I Need More Pain Medicine?**
Yes, you might need more pain medicine after surgery. They will tell you what to do when you leave the hospital.

**If You Get Sick:**
If you feel sick, get a cold, flu, or COVID-19, or if your health gets worse, call us at (650) 498-5332.

**Where to Go:**
Endoscopy is at 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, on the ground floor.

**How to Get There:**
- Go into the hospital and take the elevator to the ground floor.
- Turn right when you get out of the elevator.
- Look for the RED signs that say C06 Endoscopy and follow them.

**What to Eat and Drink:**

1. Do what your surgeon told you about eating and drinking before your surgery.

2. If your surgeon didn't tell you what to do, please follow these steps:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.

   - On the day of your surgery, take any morning medicine with small sips of water.

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.

For Endoscopy:
- Keep taking Aspirin and pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn.

**Anesthesia Pre-Op Program**
Phone: 650-555-5555

**Before Your Surgery Instructions**
Date of Surgery: 01/14/24

**When and Where for Your Surgery:**
- If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.
- The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will tell you when to come in for your surgery. They will call you the day before, or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday.
- If you haven't heard from us by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, call (650) 497-3157.

**Where to Go:**
- New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
- Address: 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital.
- Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**

1. Follow what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do:
   - No food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before surgery.
   - No milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before surgery.
   - You can have clear liquids like tea (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
   - Stop drinking clear liquids 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of surgery, take any morning medicine with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. No taxis or ride shares unless you have an adult with you.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal stuff, or contact lenses.
- Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicine Before Surgery:**
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen 1 week before. Tylenol is okay.
- If you take blood thinners, talk to your surgeon about what to do.

**About Your Anesthesia:**
- You might get a "nerve block" to help with pain during and after surgery.
- A nerve block is a shot that numbs the area for your surgery.
- Benefits: You wake up faster, less pain, less need for strong pain medicine, and less side effects.
- Types of nerve blocks:
   - Single shot: Numbs the area for 3 to 24 hours.
   - Nerve block pump: Gives medicine for 3 to 4 days.
- Risks: Like any shot, there could be infection, bleeding, or other side effects. We use special care to keep risks low.
- You'll talk to the anesthesia team before surgery to decide what's best for you.

**Surgery Day Info:**
- Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery.
- We'll call you by 6 PM the night before to tell you when to come in.

**Pain Medicine After Surgery:**
- You might need more pain medicine after surgery. We'll tell you what to do when you leave.

**If You Get Sick:**
- If you feel sick, get a cold or flu, think you've been near someone with COVID-19, or have other health changes, call us at (650) 498-5332.

Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24

**When and Where to Go for Your Surgery**

- If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.
- The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will tell you when to come in for your surgery. They'll call you the day before, or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday. If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM, call (650) 497-3157.
- Your surgery will be at the New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit. The address is 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford. Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

**What to Eat and Drink Before Surgery**

1. Follow the eating and drinking rules your doctor gave you.
2. If your doctor didn't give you rules, here's what to do:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight.
   - You can have clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
   - You can drink clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery time.
   - On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water if told to do so.

**Getting Home After Surgery**

- You need an adult to drive you home. You can't use a taxi or rideshare alone.
- Because of COVID-19, we're not offering valet parking right now.

**What to Bring and Wear**

- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things like jewelry at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses.
- Bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery**

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your doctor about what to do.

**If You Get Sick or Something Changes**

- If you feel sick, like with a cold or flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, or if you feel worse or have new symptoms, call us at (650) 498-5332.

**Where to Go:**
Byers Eye Institute Surgery Center
2452 Watson Court, Palo Alto, 1st floor

**How to Get There:**
- Walk into the Byers Eye Institute.
- Go to the back of the building and turn right to find the Surgery Center.

**What to Eat and Drink:**

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking before surgery.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, follow these steps:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
   - You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water as told.

**Getting Home:**
You need someone to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless you have a friend or family member with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
Wear comfy clothes. Leave expensive things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contacts. Bring your ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.

text:
Department: Anesthesia Preoperative Program
Phone: 650-555-5555

Hello! Here are some important things to know before your surgery:

**Your Surgery Date:** 01/14/24

**Where You Need to Go:**
- If we haven't told you the time and place for your surgery by 6:30 PM the night before, please call us at 650-723-5163.
- The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will let you know when to come in for your surgery. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to tell you when to arrive and when your surgery will start. Sometimes, the time might change. If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, call (650) 497-3157.
- **Address:** New Stanford Hospital, 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
- **How to Get There:** Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**

1. Listen to what your surgeon tells you about eating and drinking.
2. If your surgeon didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should follow:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't drink milk, soy drinks, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
   - You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of your surgery, take any morning medicine with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
- You need to have an adult drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless another adult is with you.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things like jewelry at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses.
- Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your surgeon about what to do.

**About Nerve Blocks:**
- A nerve block is a shot that makes part of your body numb for surgery.
- It helps with pain and can make you feel better faster after surgery.
- You might get a single shot or a little pump that gives medicine for a few days.
- There are some risks, but we use special tools to keep you safe.
- You'll talk to the anesthesia team on the day of your surgery to decide what's best for you.

**Day of Surgery:**
- Please come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery.
- We'll call you by 6 PM the night before to tell you when to come in.

**After Surgery:**
- You might need more pain medicine. We'll tell you what to do when you leave the hospital.

**If You Get Sick:**
- If you feel sick, like you have a cold, flu, or COVID-19, or if your health gets worse, call us at (650) 498-5332.

We're here to help you, so if you have any questions, just give us a call!

**Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM**
**Dept Phone: 650-555-5555**

**Before Your Surgery: What You Need to Know**

**Date of Your Surgery: 01/14/24**

**Where Your Surgery Will Happen:**
Your surgery time and place are not set yet. If we don't call you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will tell you when to come in for your surgery. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to let you know when to arrive and when your surgery will start. Remember, your surgery time might change. If you don't hear from us by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, call (650) 497-3157.

**How to Get to the New Stanford Hospital:**
Go to 500 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you walk into the main entrance.

**What to Eat and Drink Before Surgery:**

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking before surgery.

2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum starting at midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't have any milk, soy, or thick drinks like shakes starting at midnight the night before your surgery.
- You can have clear drinks like tea (no milk), black coffee (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
- Keep having clear drinks until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of your surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water if you were told to.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn 1 week before your surgery. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta), or others, talk to your doctor about what to do.

**If You Get Sick or Something Changes:**
If you start feeling sick, like you have a cold or the flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, or if any health problems you have get worse, or if you've been in the hospital recently, or if anything else worries you after you talked to us about your surgery, please call us at (650) 498-5332.

text:
Department: Anesthesia Preoperative Program
Phone: 650-555-5555

Hello! Here are some important things you need to know before your surgery:

Surgery Date: January 14, 2024

**If you don't know when or where your surgery is:**
- If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

**Where your surgery will be:**
- New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
- Address: 500 Pasteur Drive, Stanford, CA.
- Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**
1. Follow what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
   - No food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before surgery.
   - No milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight.
   - You can have clear drinks like tea (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
   - You can drink these clear drinks until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of surgery, take any morning medicine with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or rideshare is okay only if you have an adult with you.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses.
- Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen 1 week before. Tylenol is okay.
- If you take blood thinners, talk to your doctor about what to do.

**About Nerve Blocks:**
- A nerve block helps with pain during and after surgery.
- It's an injection that numbs an area of your body.
- Benefits: Quicker recovery, better pain control, less need for strong pain medicines, and pain relief for hours or days.
- Types of nerve blocks:
  1. Single injection: Numbs the area for 3 to 24 hours.
  2. Nerve block pump: Gives medicine for 3 to 4 days.
- Risks: Infection, bleeding, tissue damage, medicine reaction, or the block might not work. We use special care to lower these risks.

**Day of Surgery:**
- Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time.
- We'll call you by 6 PM the night before to tell you when to come in.

**Will you need more pain medicine?**
- Yes, your doctor might give you more pain medicine to take by mouth when you go home.

**If you get sick or have health changes:**
- If you feel sick, think you have COVID-19, your health gets worse, you've been in the hospital recently, or have new symptoms, call us at (650) 498-5332.

**Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM**
**Dept Phone:** 650-555-5555

**Preoperative Instructions**  
**Procedure Date:** 01/14/24

**Procedure Location:**  
**IMPORTANT:** If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

The Lane Surgery Center will tell you when to come in for your surgery. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to let you know your times. If you haven't heard from them by 6 PM, please call (650) 723-7125.

**Where to Go:**  
300P Operating Room at 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, Pavilion E25, Surgical Admission Unit/Anesthesia Pre-Evaluation Clinic.

**How to Get There:**  
- Go to the main hospital entrance.
- Turn left after you walk in.
- Take the "E" elevator to the 2nd floor.
- Turn left when you get off the elevator and go through the double doors.
- You'll see Pavilion E25 - Surgical Admission Unit/Anesthesia Pre-Evaluation Clinic right there.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**
1. Do what your surgery doctor told you about eating and drinking.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight either.
- You can have clear drinks like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
- You can keep having clear drinks until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of your surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare alone.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
Wear comfy clothes. Leave expensive things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses. Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your surgery doctor.

**Other Important Stuff:**
- If your surgery is at 300P, 500P, or Lane Surgery Center, bring your CPAP mask (not the machine) on the day of surgery. If you're staying overnight, bring your mask and machine (and know your settings).
- If you get sick, think you have COVID-19, your health gets worse, you've been in the hospital recently, or something new and worrying happens after you talked to the pre-surgery doctor, call us at (650) 498-5332.

Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Phone Number: 650-555-5555
Your Surgery Date: 01/14/24

**Important: If you don't know when or where your surgery is by the night before, call us at 650-723-5163 by 6:30 PM.**

The Endoscopy Lab will tell you when your surgery is. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) before 3 PM. If they don't call, please call them at (650) 736-5555.

Where your surgery is:
Endoscopy: 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, Ground floor.

How to get there:
- Go into the hospital and take the elevator to the ground floor.
- Turn right when you get off the elevator.
- Look for the RED signs that say C06 Endoscopy.

What to eat and drink:

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking before your surgery.

2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
- You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
- You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of your surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

Getting home:
You need someone to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless someone else is with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

What to bring and wear:
Wear comfy clothes and leave your valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal things, or contacts. Bring your ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Anesthesia Pre-Op Program**
**Phone:** 650-555-5555

**Pre-Op Instructions**
**Surgery Date:** 01/14/24

**Where's My Surgery?**
If we haven't told you when and where your surgery is by the night before, call us at 650-723-5163 by 6:30 PM.

**Surgery Time:**
The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will tell you when to come in. They'll call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday). Sometimes surgery times change. If you don't hear from us by 5:00 PM the day before, call 650-497-3157.

**Surgery Place:**
New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
**How to Get There:** Go to 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital. Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you walk in.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
   - No food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before surgery.
   - No milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before surgery.
   - You can have clear drinks like tea (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
   - You can drink these clear drinks until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. Taxis or ride shares are okay only if an adult is with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
Wear comfy clothes. Leave valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal things, or contact lenses. Bring your ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicine Before Surgery:**

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain meds like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and Naprosyn 1 week before. Tylenol is okay.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your surgeon.

**About Nerve Blocks:**
A nerve block is a shot that numbs an area for surgery. It helps with pain and can mean you might not need as much medicine. You might get a single shot or a pump that gives medicine for a few days. There are some risks, but we use special tools to keep it safe. You'll learn more on the day of surgery.

**Surgery Day:**
Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery.

**When Will They Call Me?**
They'll call by 6 PM the night before your surgery or on Friday if your surgery is on Monday.

**Will I Need More Pain Medicine?**
Yes, you might get more pain medicine to take by mouth. We'll tell you what to do when you leave.

**Feeling Sick?**
If you feel sick, like you have a cold, flu, or COVID-19, or if something else health-wise gets worse, call us at 650-498-5332.

- You can drink clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

Getting Home:
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare alone.

What to Bring and Wear:
- Wear comfy clothes.

Medicines Before Surgery:

text:
----------------

**Anesthesia Pre-Op Program**
**Phone:** 650-555-5555

**Before Your Surgery Instructions**
**Date of Surgery:** 01/14/24

**Where Your Surgery Will Be:**
**Time and Place:** We need to tell you when and where your surgery will be. If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will let you know when to come in for your surgery. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to tell you when to arrive and when your surgery will start. Sometimes, surgery times can change. If you haven't heard from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, please call (650) 497-3157.

**Where to Go:**
New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
**How to Get There:** Go to 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital. Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you walk in the main entrance.

**What to Eat and Drink:**

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking before your surgery.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't have any milk, soy drinks, or shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - You can have clear drinks like tea without milk, black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
   - You can keep drinking clear drinks until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of your surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water if you were told to.

**Getting Home:**
You need someone to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or rideshare is not okay unless you have a grown-up with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
Wear comfy clothes. Leave expensive things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal things, or contact lenses. Bring a picture ID, your insurance card, and you might need to pay a part of the bill.

**Medicine Before Surgery:**

- Stop taking herbal stuff and fish oil 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinner medicine, talk to your doctor about what to do.

**About Nerve Blocks:**
A nerve block is a shot that makes part of your body feel numb for surgery. It can help with pain and you might not need as much strong pain medicine. Your doctor will talk to you about it on the day of your surgery.

**Risks of Nerve Blocks:**
All medical things have some risks. With nerve blocks, you could get an infection, bleed, or have other problems. The doctor will be very careful to keep risks low.

**When to Arrive for Surgery:**
Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time.

**When Will They Call Me?**
They will call you by 6 PM the night before your surgery or on Friday evening if your surgery is on Monday.

**Will I Need More Pain Medicine?**
Yes, you might need more pain medicine that you take by mouth. They will tell you what to do when you leave the hospital.

**If You Get Sick:**
If you start feeling sick, like you have a cold or the flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, call us at (650) 498-5332.

300P Operating Room at 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, Pavilion E25, Surgical Admission Unit/Anesthesia Pre-Evaluation Clinic.

**How to Get There**
- Go to the main hospital entrance.
- Turn left after you walk in.
- Take the "E" elevator to the 2nd floor.
- Turn left when you get off the elevator and go through the double doors.

1. Do what your surgeon told you about eating and drinking.

- Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight.

- On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

- Leave valuable things like jewelry at home.

text:
Department: Anesthesia Preoperative Program
Phone Number: 650-555-5555
Before Surgery Instructions
Date of Surgery: 01/14/24
Where Your Surgery Will Happen: We haven't told you the time and place yet. If we don't call you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

The people at the Endoscopy Lab will tell you when your surgery will start. They will call you before 3 PM the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to let you know when to come in and when your surgery will begin. If they don't call by 3 PM, please call them at (650) 736-5555.

Where to Go for Your Surgery:
Endoscopy: It's at 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, on the ground floor.

How to Get There:
- Go into the hospital and take the elevator to the ground floor.
- Turn right when you get out of the elevator.
- Look for the RED signs that say C06 Endoscopy and follow them.

What to Eat and Drink:

1. Do what your surgeon or doctor told you about eating and drinking before your surgery.

2. If your surgeon didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't have any milk, soy products, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
- You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Make sure they don't have any bits in them.
- You can keep drinking these clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of your surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water as you were told.

Getting Home:
You need to have an adult ready to drive you home after your surgery. You can't use a taxi or a ride-sharing service unless another adult is with you. Right now, we're not offering valet parking because of COVID-19.

What to Bring and Wear:
Wear comfy clothes and leave your expensive stuff at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses. Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Medicines Before Surgery:
Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.

For Endoscopy:
- Keep taking Aspirin and pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn.
- If you're taking blood thinners like coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta), or others, call the Endoscopy Lab at (650) 736-5555 for instructions.

Other Important Stuff:
- If your surgery is at 300P, 500P, or Lane Surgery Center, bring your CPAP mask (not the machine) on the day of surgery. If you'll stay overnight, bring both the mask and machine (and know your settings).
- If you get sick, like with a cold or flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, or if you feel worse or have new symptoms after talking to the pre-surgery team, call us at (650) 498-5332.
