Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Getting Ready for Your Surgery
Procedure Date: January 14, 2024

What to Do if You Don't Know Your Surgery Time and Place:
- If we haven't told you when and where your surgery is by the night before, call us at 650-723-5163 by 6:30 PM.
- For surgeries on a Monday, call us the Friday before if you haven't heard from us by 5:00 PM at (650) 497-3157.

Where Your Surgery Will Be:
- Your surgery will be at the New Stanford Hospital (500P) on the 2nd floor in the Pre-Procedure Unit.
- To get there, go to 500 Pasteur Drive and use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

What to Eat and Drink Before Surgery:

1. Listen to what your surgery doctor tells you about eating and drinking before surgery.

2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't drink milk, soy drinks, or thick drinks like shakes after midnight.
- You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks without pulp.
- You can drink these clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of surgery, take any morning pills with small sips of water as told by your doctor.

Getting Home After Surgery:
- You need an adult to drive you home. You can't use a taxi or rideshare alone.
- Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

What to Bring and Wear:
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Don't bring valuable things.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contacts.
- Bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Medicines Before Surgery:
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your surgery doctor.

If You Get Sick or Something Changes:
- If you get a cold, the flu, think you might have COVID-19, feel worse, go to the hospital, or have new symptoms after your pre-surgery visit, call us at (650) 498-5332.

text:
Department: Anesthesia Preoperative Program
Phone: 650-555-5555
Surgery Date: 01/14/24

Hello! Here's what you need to know before your surgery:

**When and Where:**
- Your surgery time and place are not set yet. If we don't call you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.
- The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will call you the day before your surgery to tell you when to come in. If it's a Monday surgery, they'll call on Friday.
- If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM the day before, call 650-497-3157.
- Your surgery will be at the New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit, 500 Pasteur Dr. Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**
- Follow what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
- If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, don't eat food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before surgery. No dairy, milk, or soy products either.
- You can drink clear liquids like tea, black coffee (no cream), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with pulp in it.
- You can drink these clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or ride-share is okay only if an adult is with you.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things like jewelry at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses.
- Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin or Plavix, ask your doctor what to do.

**About Nerve Blocks:**
- A nerve block is a shot that numbs an area to help with pain during and after surgery.
- Benefits include faster recovery, better pain control, and less need for strong pain medicines.
- The block can last from 3 hours to 4 days, depending on the type.
- Your doctor will talk to you about which nerve block is best for you.
- Nerve blocks have some risks, like infection or bleeding, but we use special care to keep you safe.

**Day of Surgery:**
- Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time.
- We'll call you by 6 PM the night before to tell you when to come in.

**Pain Medicine After Surgery:**
- You might need more pain medicine after surgery. We'll give you instructions when you leave.

**If You Get Sick:**
- If you feel sick, like with a cold or flu, or if you've been near someone with COVID-19, call us at 650-498-5332.

We're here to help you! If you have questions, just give us a call.

text:
----------------

**Anesthesia Preoperative Program**
**Phone:** 650-555-5555

**Preoperative Instructions**
**Surgery Date:** 01/14/24

**What to do if you don't know your surgery time and place:**
If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

**Where your surgery will be:**
New Stanford Hospital (500P) Pre-Procedure Unit. They will tell you when to come in for your surgery the day before (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday). If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM the day before, call (650) 497-3157.

**How to get there:**
Go to 500 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit. Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter.

**Before surgery - Eating and Drinking:**

1. Follow what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, don't eat food, candy, or gum after midnight before your surgery.
3. Don't drink milk, soy, or shakes after midnight before your surgery.
4. You can drink clear liquids like tea (no cream), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
5. Stop drinking even clear liquids 4 hours before your surgery.
6. On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. Taxis or ride shares are okay only if an adult is with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

**What to bring and wear:**
Wear comfy clothes and leave your valuables at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal things, or contact lenses. Bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines before surgery:**

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen 1 week before. Tylenol is okay.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Plavix, Eliquis, or others, talk to your surgeon.

**About nerve blocks for surgery:**
A nerve block is a shot that numbs an area for surgery. It helps with pain and you might not need as much medicine. You can be awake or asleep for it. The block can last a few hours or a few days with a special pump. Your doctor will talk to you about it on the day of surgery.

**Risks of nerve blocks:**
All medical things have risks. For nerve blocks, these include infection, bleeding, or not working. We use special tools to keep it safe.

**Surgery Day:**
Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time. We'll call you by 6 PM the night before to tell you when to come.

**Will you need more pain medicine?**
Yes, you might get more pain medicine to take by mouth when you go home.

**If you get sick or have new health issues:**
Call us at (650) 498-5332 if you get a cold, flu, COVID-19, or if your health gets worse after we talked about your surgery.

**Remember:**
If you have questions or need help, just call us. We're here to make sure you're ready and safe for your surgery.

text:
Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24

Hello! You're getting ready for your surgery, and we want to make sure you know what to do. Here are some important instructions for you:

**When and Where Your Surgery Will Be:**
- We haven't set a time and place for your surgery yet. If we don't call you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.
- The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will tell you when to come in for your surgery. They will call you the day before, or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday. Sometimes, surgery times can change. If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM the day before, call (650) 497-3157.
- Your surgery will be at the New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit. The address is 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford. To get there, use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**
1. Your doctor might give you special instructions on what to eat and drink. Make sure to follow those.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's the plan:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't drink milk, soy, or shakes after midnight either.
- You can have clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it, like pulp.
- You can drink these clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of your surgery, take any morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
- You need to have an adult ready to drive you home after your surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless you have a grown-up with you. Right now, we're not offering valet parking because of COVID-19.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
- Wear comfy clothes and leave your valuable things like jewelry at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contacts.
- Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**
- Stop taking any herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Don't take pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn for 1 week before your surgery. Tylenol is okay.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your doctor about what to do.

**If You Feel Sick or Something Changes:**
- If you start feeling sick, like you have a cold or the flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, let us know. Also call us if you feel worse in any way or if something new is bothering you after your last visit before surgery. Our number is (650) 498-5332.

We're here to help you, so if you have any questions, just give us a call!

text:
Department: Anesthesia Preoperative Program
Phone: 650-555-5555

Hello! Here are some important things you need to know before your surgery:

Procedure Date: 01/14/24

Procedure Location: We haven't set a time and place for your surgery yet. If we don't call you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will tell you when to come in for your surgery. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to let you know when to arrive and when your surgery will start. Sometimes, surgery times can change. If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, please call 650-497-3157.

Where to Go:
New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit
Address: 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford
How to Get There: Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:

1. Follow the eating and drinking rules your doctor gave you.

2. If your doctor didn't give you rules, here's what to do:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't drink milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - You can drink clear liquids like tea without milk, black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
   - You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of your surgery, take your morning medicine with small sips of water.

Getting Home:
You need to have an adult drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare service unless you have an adult with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

What to Bring and Wear:
Wear comfy clothes and leave your valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses. Bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Medicines Before Surgery:

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and Naprosyn 1 week before your surgery. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your doctor about what to do.

About Your Anesthesia:

You might get a "nerve block" to help with pain during and after surgery. This is when a doctor gives you medicine to numb the area where you'll have surgery. You might stay awake or be given medicine to make you sleepy during the operation.

Benefits of a Nerve Block:
- You might wake up faster after surgery.
- It can control pain better than just taking pain pills.
- You might not need as many pain pills, which means fewer side effects like sleepiness, upset stomach, constipation, and itching.
- The numb feeling can last from 3 to 24 hours.
- If you have a "nerve block pump," it can last 3-4 days.

Types of Nerve Blocks:
- A single shot that numbs the area for 3 to 24 hours.
- A pump that gives you medicine for a few days.

Risks of Nerve Blocks:
Like any medical procedure, there are risks like infection, bleeding, damage to tissues, reaction to the medicine, or the block might not work. The doctor will use special equipment to lower these risks.

You'll talk to the anesthesia team on the morning of your surgery to ask questions and make a plan.

When to Arrive for Surgery:
Please come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time.

When Will They Call Me?
They'll call you by 6 PM the night before your surgery or on Friday evening if your surgery is on Monday.

Will I Need More Pain Medicine?
Yes, you might need more pain medicine that you take by mouth. They'll give you instructions when you leave the hospital.

If you get sick, like with a cold or flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, or if you feel worse or have been in the hospital recently, please call us at 650-498-5332.

text:
----------------

Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Before Your Surgery: What You Need to Know
Surgery Date: 01/14/24

When and Where for Your Surgery:
- If you don't know when or where your surgery is by the night before, call us at 650-723-5163 by 6:30 PM.
- The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will tell you when to come in. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to tell you your arrival time.
- If you haven't heard from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, please call (650) 497-3157.

Where to Go:
- New Stanford Hospital, 500 Pasteur Dr, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
- Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

What to Eat and Drink:

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking before your surgery.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, please follow these steps:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't have any milk, soy drinks, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
- You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
- You can drink these clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery time.
- On the day of your surgery, take any morning medicine with small sips of water.

Getting Home:
- You need an adult to drive you home after your surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare alone.

What to Bring and Wear:
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things like jewelry at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, body piercings, or contact lenses.
- Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Medicine Before Surgery:
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your doctor about what to do.

If You Get Sick or Something Changes:
- If you feel sick, like with a cold or flu, or have been near someone with COVID-19, or if your health gets worse, or if you have any new worries after talking to the anesthesia team, call us at (650) 498-5332.

text:
Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24

Hello! Here's what you need to know before your surgery:

**Procedure Time and Place:**
- If we haven't told you when and where your surgery is by the night before, please call us at 650-723-5163 by 6:30 PM.
- The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will call you the day before your surgery to tell you when to come in. If it's a Monday surgery, they'll call on Friday.
- Your surgery time might change, so if you haven't heard from us by 5:00 PM the day before, call (650) 497-3157.

**Where to Go:**
- New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
- Address: 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital.
- Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**
- Follow what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
- If your doctor didn't tell you anything, here's what to do:
  - Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
  - Don't drink milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight either.
  - You can have clear liquids like tea (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
  - Stop drinking even clear liquids 4 hours before your surgery.
  - On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
- Make sure an adult can drive you home after surgery. A taxi or rideshare is okay only if a responsible adult is with you.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
- Dress in comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things like jewelry at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses.
- Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen 1 week before. Tylenol is okay.
- If you take blood thinners, talk to your surgeon about what to do.

**About Nerve Blocks:**
- A nerve block is a shot that numbs an area for surgery.
- It can help you feel better faster and need fewer pain medicines.
- The block can last from 3 hours to a few days.
- Your doctor will talk to you about which type is best for you.

**Risks of Nerve Blocks:**
- Like any medical thing, there are risks like infection or not working right.
- We use special tools to keep risks low.

**Day of Surgery:**
- Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time.
- We'll call you by 6 PM the night before to tell you when to come in.

**Pain Medicine:**
- You might get more pain medicine to take by mouth when you go home.

**If You Get Sick:**
- If you feel sick or think you've been near someone with COVID-19, call us at (650) 498-5332.

Remember, we're here to help you. If you have questions, just give us a call!

- Turn left when you get off the elevator and go through the two doors.

**What to Eat and Drink Before Surgery:**
1. Follow what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.

- Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before.
- You can have clear drinks like tea without milk, black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
- You can keep having clear drinks until 4 hours before your surgery.

- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses.

Date of Surgery: 01/14/24
Location: We'll tell you when and where your surgery is. If you don't know by 6:30 PM the night before, call 650-723-5163.

The Endoscopy Lab will call you by 3 PM the day before your surgery (or Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to tell you when to come in. If they don't call, please ring (650) 736-5555.

Where to Go:
Endoscopy is at 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, on the ground floor.

How to Get There:
- Go into the hospital and take the elevator down to the ground floor.
- Turn right when you leave the elevator.
- Look for the RED signs that say C06 Endoscopy.

What to Eat and Drink:

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking before surgery.

2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before.
- You can have clear drinks like tea (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
- You can drink these clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

Getting Home:
You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare alone.

What to Bring and Wear:
Wear comfy clothes. Leave expensive things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contacts. Bring your ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.

For Endoscopy:
Keep taking Aspirin and pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen. If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, or Brilinta, call Endoscopy at (650) 736-5555 for instructions.

**Where Your Surgery Will Be:**
You'll get a call with your surgery time and place. If you don't hear from us by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, call 650-723-5163.

**Surgery Place:**
New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit
**How to Get There:** Go to 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital. Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you walk in.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**

1. Follow what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
3. Don't drink milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight.
4. You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
5. Stop drinking even clear liquids 4 hours before your surgery.
6. On the day of your surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or rideshare is okay only if an adult comes with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before surgery.

You might get a "nerve block" to help with pain. It's a shot that numbs the area for your surgery. It can help you feel better faster and need less pain medicine. The block can last from 3 hours to a few days. Your doctor will talk to you about it on your surgery day.

**Risks of Nerve Blocks:**
All medical things have risks. For nerve blocks, these can be infection, bleeding, or not working well. Your doctor will be careful to keep risks low.

**Surgery Day Info:**
Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time. You'll get a call by 6 PM the night before with the time.

**Will I Need More Pain Medicine?**
Yes, you might get more pain medicine to take by mouth when you go home.

**If You Get Sick:**
If you feel sick, get a cold or flu, think you might have COVID-19, or your health gets worse, call us at (650) 498-5332.

- Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.

text:
----------------

Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Before Your Surgery Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24

When and Where for Your Surgery:
- We need to tell you when and where your surgery will be. If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

- The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will call you the day before your surgery to tell you when to come in. If it's a Monday surgery, they'll call on Friday. If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM, call (650) 497-3157.

- Your surgery will be at the New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit, 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford. Take Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side after you enter.

What to Eat and Drink:
1. Follow what your doctor told you about eating and drinking before your surgery.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery. No dairy, milk, or soy drinks either.
3. You can have clear drinks like tea without milk, black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
4. You can drink these clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
5. On the day of your surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

Getting Home:
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or ride service is okay only if an adult is with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

What to Bring and Wear:
- Wear comfy clothes. Leave valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses. Bring a photo ID, your insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Medicines Before Surgery:
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Don't take pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn for 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your surgeon about what to do.

About Your Anesthesia:
- You might get a "nerve block" to help with pain. This means we give you medicine to numb the area for your surgery.
- Benefits of a nerve block: You wake up faster, have less pain, need fewer strong pain medicines, and have less chance of feeling sick or itchy. The numb feeling can last from 3 hours to 4 days.
- Types of nerve blocks: A single shot that lasts a short time, or a pump that gives medicine for a few days.
- Risks: Like all treatments, there are some risks, like infection or not working well. We use special tools to keep risks low.
- You'll talk to the anesthesia team on the day of your surgery to decide what's best for you.

When to Arrive:
- Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time.

Pain Medicine:
- You might need more pain medicine after the nerve block. Your doctor will tell you what to take when you go home.

If You Get Sick:
- If you feel sick, think you have COVID-19, or your health changes before your surgery, call us at (650) 498-5332.

Preoperative Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24

Procedure Location: We haven't confirmed your surgery time and place yet. If we don't call you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will tell you when your surgery will start. They'll call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to let you know when to arrive and when your surgery will begin. Your surgery time might change. If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, please call (650) 497-3157.

Where to Go:
New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit
Address: 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital
How to Get There: Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side after you enter the main lobby.

What to Eat and Drink:

1. Follow the eating and drinking rules your surgeon gave you.

2. If you didn't get instructions, here's what to do:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't drink milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
- You can drink clear liquids like tea, black coffee (no cream), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
- You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of your surgery, take your morning medicine with small sips of water.

Getting Home:
You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare alone. Because of COVID-19, we don't have valet parking right now.

What to Bring and Wear:
Wear comfy clothes and leave valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses. Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Medicine Before Surgery:

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your surgeon for more instructions.

About Your Anesthesia:

You might get a "nerve block" for your surgery. This is a shot that numbs the area and helps with pain. You might stay awake, get sleepy medicine, or be asleep during surgery.

Benefits of a nerve block:
- You might wake up faster after surgery.
- It can control pain better than some pain medicines.
- You might not need as many pain medicines, which means fewer side effects like sleepiness, upset stomach, constipation, and itching.
- The numb feeling can last 3 to 24 hours.
- With a "nerve block pump," it can last 3 to 4 days.

What kind of nerve block will I get?
Your doctor will talk to you about your choices on the day of your surgery.

Risks of a nerve block:
All medical treatments have risks. With a nerve block, you might get an infection, bleed, or have damage to tissues. You might have a reaction to the medicine, or it might not work. The doctor will use special tools and clean methods to lower these risks.

When to Arrive for Surgery:
Please come 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery.

When Will They Call Me?
They'll call you by 6 PM the night before your surgery or on Friday evening if your surgery is on Monday.

Will I need more pain medicine?
Yes, you might need more pain medicine that you take by mouth. They'll give you instructions when you leave.

If you get sick, like with a cold or flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, or if you feel worse or have new symptoms, please call us at (650) 498-5332.

Procedure Date: January 14, 2024
Procedure Location: WE NEED TO TELL YOU WHEN AND WHERE. If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will let you know when to come in for your surgery. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to tell you when to arrive and when your surgery will start. Sometimes surgery times can change. If you don't hear from us by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, please call (650) 497-3157.

Where to Go:
New Stanford Hospital. HOW TO GET THERE: The hospital is at 500 Pasteur Drive, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side after you enter the main lobby.

What to Eat and Drink:

1. Do what your surgery doctor told you about eating and drinking before your surgery.

2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum starting at midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't have any milk, soy drinks, or protein shakes starting at midnight the night before your surgery.
- You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee (no cream), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
- You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery. On the day of your surgery, take any morning pills with small sips of water.

Getting Home:
Make sure an adult can drive you home after your surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare alone. Because of COVID-19, we're not doing Valet parking right now.

What to Bring and Wear:
Wear comfy clothes. Leave expensive things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, body piercings, or contact lenses. Bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Medicine Before Surgery:
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain relievers like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta), or others, talk to your surgery doctor.

Other Important Stuff:
If you get sick, like a cold or the flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, or if you feel worse or have been in the hospital recently, or if anything else worries you after your pre-surgery visit, please call us at (650) 498-5332.

text:
----------------

**Anesthesia Pre-Op Program**
**Phone:** 650-555-5555

**Before Your Surgery Instructions**
**Date of Surgery:** 01/14/24

**Where Your Surgery Will Be:**
**Important:** If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

The Pre-Procedure Unit at the New Stanford Hospital (500P) will tell you when to come in for your surgery. They'll call you the day before (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to let you know when to arrive and when your surgery will start. Sometimes, surgery times can change. If you don't hear from us by 5:00 PM the day before, call (650) 497-3157.

**Where to Go:**
New Stanford Hospital (500P)
**How to Get There:** Go to 500 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit. Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you walk into the main entrance.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before.
   - You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
   - You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
You need someone to drive you home after surgery. A taxi or rideshare is okay only if a grown-up is with you.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
Wear comfy clothes. Leave valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal things, or contacts. Bring your ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay something.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**

- Stop taking herbal stuff and fish oil 1 week before.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Plavix, or others, ask your doctor what to do.

**About Your Anesthesia:**
You might get a "nerve block" to help with pain. It's a shot that makes part of your body feel numb. It can help you feel better faster and need less pain medicine. The block can last from a few hours to a few days. Your doctor will talk to you about it on the day of surgery.

**Risks of a Nerve Block:**
All treatments have risks. For a nerve block, these could be infection, bleeding, or not working right. We use special tools to keep risks low.

**When to Arrive for Surgery:**
Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time.

**When Will They Call Me?**
They'll call you by 6 PM the night before, or on Friday for a Monday surgery.

**Will I Need More Pain Medicine?**
Yes, you might need more pain medicine that you take by mouth. We'll tell you what to do when you leave the hospital.

**If You Get Sick:**
If you feel sick, get a cold or flu, think you have COVID-19, or your health gets worse, call us at (650) 498-5332.

Department: Anesthesia Pre-Op Program
Phone: 650-555-5555
Before Surgery Instructions
Date of Surgery: 01/14/24
Where Your Surgery Will Be: We need to tell you when and where your surgery will be. If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will let you know when your surgery will start. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to tell you when to arrive and when your surgery will begin. Your surgery time might change. If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, please call (650) 497-3157.

Where to Go:
New Stanford Hospital (500P), 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
How to Get There: Take Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

What You Can Eat and Drink:

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking before your surgery.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't drink milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - You can drink clear liquids like tea without milk, black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Don't drink anything with bits in it.
   - You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of your surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water as told.

Getting Home:
You need someone over 18 to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless you have an adult with you. We're not doing valet parking because of COVID-19.

What to Bring and Wear:
Wear comfy clothes. Leave valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses. Bring your ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Medicine Before Surgery:
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your doctor for instructions.

About Your Anesthesia:
You might get a "nerve block" to help with pain during and after surgery. A doctor will give you medicine to numb the area. You might stay awake or sleep during surgery.

Benefits of a Nerve Block:
- You wake up faster after surgery.
- It controls pain better than just using pain pills.
- You might not need as many pain pills, so you'll have fewer side effects like sleepiness, upset stomach, constipation, and itching.
- Pain relief can last 3-24 hours or even 3-4 days with a special pump.

Types of Nerve Blocks:
- Single injection: One shot of medicine to numb the area for 3-24 hours.
- Nerve block pump: A tiny tube stays on your skin to give medicine for 3-4 days.

Risks of Nerve Blocks:
All medical treatments have risks. These can include infection, bleeding, damage to tissues, reaction to the medicine, or the block might not work. The doctor will use special tools to lower these risks.

You'll talk to the anesthesia team on the day of your surgery to decide what's best for you.

When to Arrive for Surgery:
Please come 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time.

When Will They Call Me?
They'll call you by 6 PM the night before your surgery or on Friday evening if your surgery is on Monday.

Will I Need More Pain Medicine?
Yes, your doctor might give you more pain pills. You'll get instructions when you leave the hospital.

If you get sick, think you have COVID-19, your health gets worse, you go to the hospital, or you have new symptoms after your pre-op visit, call us at (650) 498-5332.

- Turn left when you get off the elevator and go through the double doors.
- You'll see Pavilion E25 - Surgical Admission Unit/Anesthesia Pre-Evaluation Clinic right there.

**What to Eat and Drink Before Surgery:**
1. Listen to what your surgery doctor tells you about eating and drinking.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
- Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
- Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
- You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Make sure there's no pulp in them.
- You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On the day of your surgery, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home After Surgery:**
- You need to have an adult ready to drive you home. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless you have an adult with you.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave your valuable things at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses.
- Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and Naprosyn 1 week before your surgery. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your surgery doctor.

**Other Important Info:**
- If you use a CPAP mask for sleep, bring it on the day of your surgery. If you're staying overnight, bring your mask and machine (and know your settings).
- If you get sick, like a cold or flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, or if you feel worse or have new symptoms, call us at (650) 498-5332.

text:
----------------

**Anesthesia Pre-Op Program**
**Phone:** 650-555-5555

**Before Your Surgery Instructions**

**Date of Surgery:** 01/14/24

**Where Your Surgery Will Be:**
If we haven't told you the time and place for your surgery by 6:30 PM the night before, please call us at 650-723-5163.

The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will let you know when to come in for your surgery. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to tell you when to arrive and when your surgery will start. Sometimes surgery times can change. If you don't hear from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, call (650) 497-3157.

**Where to Go:**
New Stanford Hospital (500P), 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital.
Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**

1. Do what your doctor told you about eating and drinking before surgery.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - You can have clear drinks like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
   - You can keep drinking clear drinks until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of your surgery, take any morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
You need to have an adult ready to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless another adult is with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
Wear comfy clothes. Leave valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal things, or contact lenses. Bring a photo ID, your insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicine Before Surgery:**

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your doctor about what to do.

**About Your Anesthesia:**

You might get a "nerve block" to help with pain during and after surgery. This is when a doctor gives you a shot to numb the area where you'll have surgery. It can help you feel better faster and need less pain medicine. The numb feeling can last from 3 hours to a few days. Your doctor will talk to you about what kind of nerve block is best for you.

**Risks of a Nerve Block:**
Like any medical thing, there are risks, like infection, bleeding, or the medicine not working. The doctor will use special tools to keep risks low. You'll meet the anesthesia team on the day of your surgery to talk more about it.

**When to Arrive for Surgery:**
Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery.

**When Will They Call Me?**
They'll call you by 6 PM the night before your surgery or on Friday evening if your surgery is on Monday.

**Will I Need More Pain Medicine?**
Yes, you might need more pain medicine that you take by mouth. They'll tell you what to do when you leave the hospital.

**If You Get Sick:**
If you feel sick, like with a cold or flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, or if you just feel worse, call us at (650) 498-5332.

Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24

**Procedure Location:**
- If we haven't told you your surgery time and place by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

**Where to Go for Your Surgery:**
- New Stanford Hospital (500P) Pre-Procedure Unit.
- Address: 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
- How to Get There: Take Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**
- Follow what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
- If your doctor didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
  - Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
  - Don't drink milk, soy drinks, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
  - You can drink clear liquids like tea, black coffee (no cream), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
  - You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
  - On the day of your surgery, take any morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless an adult is with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses.
- Bring your photo ID and insurance card. You might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, and Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin, Lovenox, Plavix, Eliquis, Pradaxa, Xarelto, Brilinta, or others, talk to your doctor for more instructions.

**About Your Anesthesia:**
- You might get a "nerve block" to help with pain during and after surgery.
- A nerve block is a shot that numbs the area for your surgery.
- Benefits of a nerve block:
  - You wake up faster.
  - It controls pain better than just pain pills.
  - You might not need as many pain pills, so you'll have fewer side effects.
  - The numbing can last from 3 hours to 3-4 days, depending on the type.
- Your doctor will talk to you about what kind of nerve block is best for you on the day of your surgery.

**Risks of a Nerve Block:**
- Like any medical procedure, there are risks like infection, bleeding, or damage to tissues.
- The doctor will use special equipment to lower these risks.

**Surgery Day Info:**
- You should come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery.
- We'll call you by 6 PM the night before your surgery to tell you when to come in.

**Will I Need More Pain Medicine?**
- Yes, you might need more pain medicine that you take by mouth. We'll give you instructions when you leave.

**If You Get Sick:**
- If you feel sick, like with a cold or flu, or if you've been around someone with COVID-19, or if you have new health problems, call us at (650) 498-5332.

Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Before Your Surgery Instructions
Date of Your Surgery: 01/14/24
Where Your Surgery Will Happen: WE NEED TO TELL YOU THE TIME AND PLACE. If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call 650-723-5163.

The New Stanford Hospital (500P) Pre-Procedure Unit will let you know when your surgery will start. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to tell you when to arrive and when your surgery will begin. Your surgery time might change. If you haven't heard from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, please call (650) 497-3157.

Where to Go for Your Surgery:
New Stanford Hospital (500p).
HOW TO GET THERE: The hospital is at 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.

Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side after you enter the main lobby.

What You Can Eat and Drink:

1. Do what your doctor tells you about eating and drinking before your surgery.

2. If your doctor hasn't told you what to do, please follow these steps:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't drink milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - You can drink clear liquids like tea without milk, black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Don't drink anything with bits in it.
   - You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of your surgery, take your morning medicine with small sips of water.

Getting Home:
Make sure an adult can drive you home after your surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless another adult is with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

What to Bring and Wear:
Wear comfy clothes. Leave valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses. Bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

Medicine Before Surgery:
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, Ibuprofen, Motrin, or Naprosyn 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like coumadin (Warfarin), Lovenox (enoxaparin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), ticagrelor (Brilinta), or others, talk to your doctor for more instructions.

Other Important Info:
Your Anesthesia Plan
Depending on your surgery, you might get a special kind of pain medicine called regional anesthesia or a "nerve block."

What's a "nerve block"?
It's a shot that numbs part of your body to help with pain during and after surgery. A special doctor gives you this shot.

Why is a nerve block good?
- You might wake up faster after surgery.
- It can control pain better than some other pain medicines.
- You might not need as many pain pills, so you'll have fewer side effects like sleepiness, upset stomach, constipation, and itching.
- The numb feeling can last 3-24 hours or even 3-4 days with a special pump.

What kind of nerve block will I get?
Your doctor will talk to you about the best choice on your surgery day.

Are there risks with a nerve block?
Yes, like with any medical thing, there can be risks like infection, bleeding, or damage to tissues. The doctor will use special tools to keep risks low.

When should I come in for surgery?
Please arrive 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery.

When will they call me with my surgery time?
They'll call you by 6 PM the night before your surgery or on Friday evening if your surgery is on Monday.

Will I need more pain medicine with a nerve block?
Yes, your doctor might give you more pain medicine to take by mouth. You'll get instructions when you leave the hospital.

If you get sick, like with a cold or flu, or if you've been near someone with COVID-19, or if you feel worse or have new symptoms, please call us at (650) 498-5332.

**Anesthesia Pre-Op Program**
**Phone:** 650-555-5555
**Surgery Date:** 01/14/24

**Important:**
If we haven't called you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.

**Where to Go:**
New Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit
**Address:** 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford
**How to Get There:** Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**

1. Follow what your doctor told you about eating and drinking.
2. If your doctor didn't tell you what to do:
   - Don't eat food, candy, or chew gum after midnight the night before.
   - Don't have milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight.
   - You can have clear drinks like tea (no milk), water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
   - You can drink these clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - Take your morning pills with small sips of water on the day of surgery.

**Getting Home:**
You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. Taxis or ride shares are not okay unless you have an adult with you.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
Wear comfy clothes. Leave valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal things, or contact lenses. Bring your ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**

- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Plavix, or others, talk to your surgeon.

**About Your Anesthesia:**

You might get a "nerve block" to help with pain. This is a shot that numbs the area for your surgery. It can help you feel better faster and need less pain medicine. The numb feeling can last from 3 hours to a few days. Your doctor will talk to you about it on the day of surgery.

**Risks:**
All treatments have risks. For a nerve block, these include infection, bleeding, or not working as expected. We use special tools to keep risks low.

**Day of Surgery:**

- Please arrive 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery time.
- We'll call you by 6 PM the night before to tell you when to come in.

**Will I need more pain medicine?**
Yes, you might need more pain medicine that you take by mouth. We'll tell you what to do when you leave the hospital.

**If You Get Sick:**
If you feel sick, like a cold or flu, or if you've been near someone with COVID-19, or if you feel worse in any way, call us at (650) 498-5332.

Department: ANESTHESIA PREOPERATIVE PROGRAM
Dept Phone: 650-555-5555
Preoperative Instructions
Procedure Date: 01/14/24

**Procedure Time and Place:**
If we haven't told you when and where your surgery is by the night before at 6:30 PM, please call us at 650-723-5163.

The New Stanford Hospital Pre-Procedure Unit will let you know when to come in for your surgery. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday) to tell you your arrival and surgery times. Sometimes, these times might change. If you haven't heard from them by 5:00 PM the day before your surgery, call (650) 497-3157.

**Where to Go:**
New Stanford Hospital (500P)
Directions: 500 Pasteur Dr, Stanford Hospital, 2nd floor, Pre-Procedure Unit.
Use Elevator M (numbers 5, 6, 7, or 8) on the right side when you enter the main lobby.

**Eating and Drinking Before Surgery:**

1. Do what your surgeon told you about eating and drinking before surgery.
2. If your surgeon didn't tell you what to do, here's what you should do:
   - Don't eat any food, candy, or gum after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - Don't have any milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight the night before your surgery.
   - You can drink clear liquids like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. Nothing with bits in it.
   - You can keep drinking clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
   - On the day of your surgery, take any morning pills with small sips of water.

**Getting Home:**
You need to have an adult drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare unless an adult is with you. Right now, we don't have valet parking because of COVID-19.

**What to Bring and Wear:**
Wear comfy clothes and leave your valuable things at home. Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal piercings, or contact lenses. Bring your photo ID, insurance card, and you might need to pay a co-payment or deductible.

**Medicines Before Surgery:**
- Stop taking herbal supplements and fish oils 1 week before your surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicines like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Plavix, or others, talk to your surgeon about what to do.

**About Nerve Blocks:**
A nerve block is a shot that numbs part of your body to help with pain during and after surgery. An expert doctor gives you this shot. You might be awake, sleepy, or asleep when you get it.

**Benefits of a Nerve Block:**
- You might wake up faster after surgery.
- It can control pain better than some pain medicines.
- You might need fewer pain medicines, which means fewer side effects like feeling sleepy or sick.
- The numb feeling can last from 3 hours to 24 hours.
- With a special pump, it can last up to 3-4 days.

**Types of Nerve Blocks:**
- A single shot that lasts a short time.
- A pump that gives medicine for a few days.

**Risks of Nerve Blocks:**
All medical treatments have risks. For nerve blocks, these can include infection, bleeding, or not working well. The doctor will use special tools to lower these risks.

**Surgery Day Info:**
- Come in 2 to 2 and a half hours before your surgery.
- We'll call you by 6 PM the night before your surgery to tell you when to come in.

**Will I Need More Pain Medicine?**
Yes, you might get more pain medicine to take by mouth. We'll tell you what to do when you leave the hospital.

**If You Get Sick:**
If you feel sick, get a cold or the flu, think you have COVID-19, or your health gets worse, call us at (650) 498-5332.

text:
Department: Anesthesia Pre-Op Program
Phone: 650-555-5555

Before Surgery Instructions
Date of Surgery: 01/14/24

When and Where:
- Your surgery time and place are not set yet. If we don't call you by 6:30 PM the night before your surgery, please call us at 650-723-5163.
- The Lane Surgery Center will tell you when to come in. They will call you the day before your surgery (or on Friday if your surgery is on a Monday). If you don't hear from them by 6 PM, call (650) 723-7125.
- Your surgery will be at 300P Operating Room, 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford Hospital, Pavilion E25, Surgical Admission Unit/Anesthesia Pre-Evaluation Clinic.

How to Get There:
- Go in the main hospital door.
- Turn left right after you walk in.
- Take the "E" elevator to the 2nd floor.
- Turn left when you get off the elevator and go through the two doors.
- You'll see Pavilion E25 - Surgical Admission Unit/Anesthesia Pre-Evaluation Clinic.

What to Eat and Drink:
1. Do what your surgeon tells you about eating and drinking before surgery.
2. If your surgeon didn't tell you what to do, follow these steps:
- No food, candy, or gum after midnight before your surgery.
- No milk, soy, or protein shakes after midnight before your surgery.
- You can have clear drinks like tea (no milk), black coffee, water, cranberry juice, apple juice, or sports drinks. No drinks with bits in them.
- You can drink clear liquids until 4 hours before your surgery.
- On surgery day, take your morning pills with small sips of water.

Getting Home:
- You need an adult to drive you home after surgery. You can't use a taxi or rideshare alone.

What to Bring and Wear:
- Wear comfy clothes.
- Leave valuable things at home.
- Don't wear makeup, jewelry, metal, or contacts.
- Bring a photo ID and your insurance card. You might need to pay a part of the cost.

Medicine Before Surgery:
- Stop taking herbal stuff and fish oil 1 week before surgery.
- Stop taking pain medicine like Advil, Aleve, or Ibuprofen 1 week before. You can take Tylenol.
- If you take blood thinners like Warfarin, Plavix, or others, ask your surgeon what to do.

Other Stuff:
- If you use a CPAP mask for sleep, bring it on the day of surgery. If you're staying overnight, bring the mask and machine.
- If you get sick, think you have COVID-19, or have new health problems after your pre-op visit, call us at (650) 498-5332.
